docs.title: Contributions
docs.text:
This is a personal knowledge base, but feel free to get inspired to create your own.

Made with MkDocs

docs.title: 1. Initialize a Git Repository
docs.text:
git init

This creates a .git/ folder in your project, enabling version control.

docs.title: 2. Clone a Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git

Clones a remote repository to your local machine.

docs.title: 3. Check Repository Status
docs.text:
git status

Shows changes, staged files, and the current branch.

docs.title: 4. Add Files to Staging Area
docs.text:
git add filename.txt
# or add all changes
git add .

Adds files to be included in the next commit.

docs.title: 5. Commit Changes
docs.text:
git commit -m "Describe what you changed"

Saves the staged changes with a message.

docs.title: 6. View Commit History
docs.text:
git log

Displays the list of commits with hash, author, and message.

docs.title: 7. Create a New Branch
docs.text:
git checkout -b feature-branch

Creates and switches to a new branch.

docs.title: 8. Switch Branch
docs.text:
git checkout main

Changes to the specified branch.

docs.title: 9. Merge a Branch
docs.text:
git checkout main
git merge feature-branch

Merges the feature-branch into main.

docs.title: 10. Push to Remote Repository
docs.text:
git push origin main

Pushes your local commits to the remote GitHub repository.

docs.title: 11. Pull Latest Changes
docs.text:
git pull origin main

Fetches and merges changes from the remote repo.

docs.title: 12. Set Remote URL
docs.text:
git remote add origin https://github.com/user/repo.git

Links your local repo to a remote one.

docs.title: 13. View Configurations
docs.text:
git config --list

Shows your Git configuration (user, email, etc.)

docs.title: 14. Undo Last Commit (but keep changes)
docs.text:
git reset --soft HEAD~1

Moves the last commit back to staged area.

docs.title: 15. Remove a File from Git (but keep it locally)
docs.text: git rm --cached filename.txt

docs.title: How to Create and Use a Python Virtual Environment (venv)
1. Check if Python is Installed
docs.text:
python3 --version

If Python is not installed, download it from:

https://www.python.org/downloads/

docs.title: 2. Create the Virtual Environment
docs.text:
In your project folder, run:

python3 -m venv venv

This will create a folder called venv/ containing your isolated Python environment.

docs.title: On macOS / Linux:
docs.text: source venv/bin/activate

docs.title: On Windows (CMD):
docs.text: venv\\Scripts\\activate

docs.title: On Windows (PowerShell):
docs.text:
.\\venv\\Scripts\\Activate.ps1

After activation, you should see (venv) at the beginning of your terminal prompt.

docs.title: 4. Install Your Packages
docs.text:
With the environment active:

pip install requests flask

These packages are installed only inside venv/.

docs.title: 5. Deactivate the Environment
docs.text:
To exit the virtual environment:

deactivate

docs.title: 6. Add venv/ to .gitignore
docs.text:
If you're using Git, make sure to ignore the virtual environment:

echo "venv/" >> .gitignore

docs.title: Bonus: Recreate Environment from requirements.txt
docs.text:
To save your current packages:

pip freeze > requirements.txt

To recreate the same environment later:

python3 -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate
pip install -r requirements.txt
